items.message: The tides have now passed and no further flooding is expected. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Cornwall Coast, Tidal Fal Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Sunday evening. High water at Falmouth is at 6:00pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

High water levels are forecast to cause flooding between 5.00pm and 7:00pm. 

Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas in Falmouth, Penryn, Flushing, Mylor Bridge and the A39 at Perranarworthal. 

Waterside locations and roads along the estuary may be flooded. Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

Coastal conditions should ease for Monday morning's high tide, however, conditions are forecast to worsen from Tuesday evening, bringing a further risk of flooding. Flood alerts and warnings will be issued if required. 

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday Monday, or if the situation changes. The tidal gates at Flushing have been closed. 

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide at Falmouth is 2.55 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.2m above tide table level. Strong force 5 southwesterly winds and offshore waves of up to 2m are forecast over the high tide.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast this afternoon, 08/09/2025. 
We do not anticipate the flood alert level to be met during this afternoon’s high tide, but flooding is still possible at low lying lands and roads from 12:45 PM on 08/09/2025 at the following locations: 
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 1:15 PM 
Eastford Road, peaking around 1:30 PM 
Arpley Bridge, peaking around 1:45 PM 
It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 09/09/2025. 
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.   
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 08/09/2025, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

The lunchtime tide on Monday, 8 September 2025, is not expected to meet the flood alert criteria. However, the following three tides (Monday evening and the two high tides on Tuesday) are expected to do so, as we move towards the peak anticipated on Thursday, 11 September. None of these high tides are currently forecast to cause property flooding.
Please avoid driving through flood water and do not put yourself or others at risk.
We will re-issue the flood alert by 3pm this afternoon, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
The tide at 12:30 lunchtime on Monday 08/09/2025 is not forecast to reach flood alert level, however the tide at midnight on Monday 08/09/25 night will. High tides will be experienced for much of the coming week. High tides tonight may lead to flooding of low lying land and roads.

Flooding is possible around the high tide from 12:00 midnight on Monday 08/09/2025.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.

We are closely monitoring the situation.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 6:00 PM on 08/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook
